Award.AwardTitle: The Typology of Handshape: Gesture, Homesign, and Sign Language

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will answer two related questions concerning differences and similaarities across signed languages. Both are addressed by analyzing the patterns of the handshapes produced in gesture, homesign and sign languages. First, are some language-specific differences in sign languages attributable to typological class (rather than to random variation or historical relatedness)? The typological distinction involves two types of iconicity used in handshape (hand-as-object vs. hand-as-hand) and how they are distributed throughout the grammar -- in nouns, verbs, and productive morphology. The study will include signers from four countries: the United States, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong, and Italy. Typology has been an important tool in predicting variation among spoken languages, and typology is hypothesized to have the same explanatory power in signed languages.

The second question to be addressed is: How do differences among sign languages emerge? Are the patterns of iconicity in handshape shared by a particular sign language and the surrounding culturally specific gestures used by hearing people? Or do handshape patterns emerge only when gesture is used as the primary means of communication (homesign and sign language)? Gesturers, homesigners, and signers from Nicaragua will be involved in answering this question, along with a control group of gesturers from each of the countries mentioned above. It is expected that gesture systems will pattern differently with respect to sign languages and homesign, which are expected to behave more similarly to one another. If confirmed, this will be evidence that sign language patterns are not continuous with those of the surrounding gestural patterns that hearing people use, but rather stem from continued use of gesture as the sole means of communication. This will shed light on the "nature" vs. "nurture" question. Since it is no longer possible to trace the change from "non-language" to "language" in speech, this work contributes to our understanding of the emergence of language.

In addition to providing a better understanding of the properties of signed languages and the factors that influence variation among them, this project will enable the development of improved methods for assessing typical and atypical SL development. The project will also provide valuable training opportunities for undergraduate students, and will enable the creation of new, international scientific collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project had two major goals. The first was to understand how much variation there is in the kinds of handshapes that sign languages use to create form-meaning pairings, and the second goal was to better understand how such form-meaning pairs involving handshape emerge as a part of grammar; i.e., how handshapes emerge as linguistic objects. Two types of iconic handshapes are common across the world's sign languages: handshapes that represent how objects are manipulated (called handling handshapes), and handshapes that represent the shape of objects (what objects look like). These two handshape types were the focus of both of the studies of this project. Participants in both studies were asked to describe short videos that we showed them.

Intellectual Merit: To understand variation across sign languages, in Study 1 we analyzed handling and object handshapes in four unrelated sign languages with relatively long histories (over 200 years) in a wide range of linguistic contexts in order to see the extent to which the same kinds of events in the world are labeled and described in the same way across sign languages. The four languages were American Sign Language, British Sign Language, Hong Kong Sign Language, and Italian Sign Language. The findings reveal that while there are similarities in the kinds of form-meaning pairs used across sign languages, sign languages also differ in whether they prefer to use handling or object handshapes in nouns and verbs, and in whether these handshapes are used alone or in combination to create complex meanings.

The handshapes that hearing people (non-signers) use without their voices using only their hands (i.e., silent gesture) in each of these four countries were also analyzed to investigate whether being a signer or non-signer predicted handshape patterns, and also whether the country a person is from (the USA, Great Britain, Hong Kong, Italy) was related to their handshape patterns. Overall, it turned out that being a deaf signer (rather than a hearing non-signer) had more impact on handshape use than the country a person was from; however, some hearing non-signers in Italy and Nicaragua did produced handshape patterns that were similar to those produced by deaf signers.

To understand how handshapes become linguistic (Study 2), we traveled to Nicaragua, where a very young sign language began developing when deaf people came together at two schools for deaf people in the late 1970s. This new language is only about 50 years old -- much younger than spoken languages, which can be thousands of years old, or than the sign languages in Study 1. Four groups of Nicaraguans participated in this work: 1) Hearing gesturers (i.e., non-signers) using silent gesture; 2) Deaf homesigners, who are deaf individuals who live with hearing people who do not know a sign language, and who are not part of the deaf community who uses the new sign language, and 3) and 4) two groups of deaf signers who use the new language, Nicaraguan Sign Language (NSL), to communicate with other members of the signing community. Some NSL signers have had the experience of signing at school with other deaf people, (cohort 1), while other NSL signers not only communicate with other signers at the school, but also learned from the students who were there when they arrived (cohort 2). Homesigners provide crucial information about the point at which a gesture becomes linguistic, because no one in their environment shares their system; the family is hearing, does not know a sign language, and is not proficient in the homesigner's system. Results demonstrated that while gesturers tend to have only a few, simple handshapes in their system, homesigners use a very large set of handshapes, with a lot of variation from one person to another. Some of the homesigners' handshapes are also highly complex. The analyses also showed that when deaf people can sign with one another and learn sign language from one another, or from signers of the previous generation, as they can in the NSL community, the handshape system becomes less complex and smaller (there are fewer handshapes) before it regains complexity. However, even though the set of handshapes used is smaller in NSL signers than in homesigners, the handshapes become more grammatical in their use, taking on the role of linguistic categories, such as noun and verb, and conveying complex meanings similar to those of the sign languages in Study 1.

Broader Impact: This work on handshape provides normative data against which typical and atypical sign language development can be compared, leading to more accurate identification of language delay among signing children. The results also show that hearing people possess a type of "gestural competence" that all people share, even those without sign experience. Several Deaf students and collaborators were also recruited and trained, thus increasing the number Deaf linguists working in the field.
